Answers: Lynch says investing is fun, exciting, and dangerous if you don't do any work. Research is essential for investment success.

Questions: What is Peter's Principle #16?
Answers: In business, competition is never as healthy as total domination.

Questions: What is Peter's Principle #17?
Answers: All else being equal, invest in the company with the fewest color photographs in the annual report.

Questions: What is Peter's Principle #18?
Answers: When even the analysts are bored, it's time to start buying.

Questions: What is Peter's Principle #19?
Answers: Unless you're a short seller or a poet looking for a wealthy spouse, it never pays to be pessimistic.

Questions: What is Peter's Principle #20?
Answers: Corporations, like people, change their names for one of two reasons: either they've gotten married, or they've been involved in some fiasco they hope the public will forget.

Questions: What is Peter's Principle #21?
Answers: Whatever the queen is selling, buy it.

Questions: What is Peter's Principle #4?
Answers: You can't see the future through a rearview mirror.

Questions: What is Peter's Principle #5?
Answers: There's no point paying Yo-Yo Ma to play a radio (referring to paying loads for government bond funds).

Questions: What is Peter's Principle #6?
Answers: As long as you're picking a fund, you might as well pick a good one.

Questions: What is Peter's Principle #7?
Answers: The extravagance of any corporate office is directly proportional to management's reluctance to reward the shareholders.

Questions: What is Peter's Principle #8?

Questions: What is Peter's Principle #9?
Answers: Not all common stocks are equally common.

Questions: What is Peter's Principle #12?

Questions: What is Peter's Principle #14?
Answers: If you like the store, chances are you'll love the stock.

Questions: What is Peter's Principle #15?
Answers: When insiders are buying, it's a good sign - unless they happen to be New England bankers.

Questions: What was Peter Lynch's main reason for retiring from managing the Magellan Fund?
Answers: Lynch retired primarily to spend more time with his family. He realized he was missing his children's school plays, soccer games, and other important moments while being too focused on work.

Questions: How long did Peter Lynch manage the Fidelity Magellan Fund?
Answers: Lynch managed the Magellan Fund for 13 years, from 1977 to 1990.

Questions: What is Peter's Principle #1?
Answers: When the operas outnumber the football games three to zero, you know there is something wrong with your life.

Questions: What is Peter's Principle #3?
Answers: Never invest in any idea you can't illustrate with a crayon.

Questions: What is Peter Lynch's view on investing without doing research?
Answers: Lynch says investing is fun, exciting, and dangerous if you don't do any work. Research is essential for investment success.

Questions: According to Lynch, where does your real investor's edge come from?
Answers: Lynch teaches that your investor's edge isn't from Wall Street experts - it's something you already have from your own knowledge and experience.

Questions: How does Lynch say amateur investors can outperform professionals?
Answers: Lynch believes you can outperform experts by using your edge - investing in companies or industries you already understand from daily life.

Questions: Why does Lynch think the market is now easier for amateur investors?
Answers: Lynch observes that professional investors now dominate the market in herds, which actually makes it easier for amateur investors who can ignore the herd.

Questions: What is Lynch's fundamental approach to stock analysis?
Answers: Lynch always reminds investors that behind every stock is a company - you must find out what the company is doing.

Questions: How does Lynch explain the relationship between company performance and stock prices?
Answers: Lynch notes there's often no correlation between company success and stock performance short-term, but 100% correlation long-term. This disparity is key to making money.

Questions: What must investors know about their holdings according to Lynch?
Answers: Lynch insists you must know what you own and why you own it. Saying 'this baby is a cinch to go up!' doesn't count as analysis.

Questions: What is Lynch's view on long-shot investments?
Answers: Lynch warns that long shots almost always miss the mark - focus on solid, understandable companies instead.

Questions: How does Lynch compare owning stocks to having children?
Answers: Lynch says owning stocks is like having children - don't get involved with more than you can handle. Quality over quantity.

Questions: How many companies can a part-time investor effectively follow according to Lynch?
Answers: Lynch believes part-time stockpickers can follow 8-12 companies effectively, buying and selling as conditions warrant.

Questions: What is Lynch's recommended maximum portfolio size?
Answers: Lynch suggests there don't need to be more than 5 companies in a portfolio at any one time.

Questions: What is Lynch's most important rule about company finances?
Answers: Lynch emphasizes never investing in a company without understanding its finances - always check the balance sheet for solvency first.

Questions: Where do the biggest stock losses come from according to Lynch?
Answers: Lynch warns that the biggest losses come from companies with poor balance sheets - financial strength is crucial.

Questions: What types of stocks does Lynch recommend avoiding vs. buying?
Answers: Lynch says avoid hot stocks in hot industries. Instead, buy great companies in cold, nongrowth industries - they're consistent big winners.

Questions: When should you invest in small companies according to Lynch?
Answers: Lynch recommends waiting until small companies turn a profit before investing - don't speculate on pre-profit companies.

Questions: How should you approach troubled industries according to Lynch?
Answers: Lynch suggests buying companies with staying power in troubled industries, but wait for signs of industry revival first.

Questions: What does Lynch say about investment risk vs. reward potential?
Answers: Lynch points out you can lose maximum $1,000 on a $1,000 investment, but stand to gain $10,000 or $50,000 over time with patience.

Questions: How many big winners does Lynch say you need for investment success?
Answers: Lynch believes it only takes a handful of big winners to make a lifetime of investing worthwhile.

Questions: How does Lynch want investors to view market declines?
Answers: Lynch teaches that stock market declines are as routine as January blizzards in Colorado - if prepared, they can't hurt you.

Questions: What opportunity do market declines create according to Lynch?
Answers: Lynch sees declines as great opportunities to pick up bargains left behind by panicking investors.

Questions: What does Lynch say about brainpower vs. emotional control in investing?
Answers: Lynch observes everyone has the brainpower to make money in stocks, but not everyone has the stomach for volatility.

Questions: Who should avoid stock investing according to Lynch?
Answers: Lynch warns that if you're susceptible to selling everything in a panic, you should avoid stocks and stock mutual funds altogether.

Questions: What should guide your selling decisions according to Lynch?
Answers: Lynch advises selling because company fundamentals deteriorate, not because of scary headlines or dire predictions about the economy.

Questions: What does Lynch say about economic and market predictions?
Answers: Lynch states nobody can predict interest rates, future economic direction, or stock market movements - dismiss all such forecasts.

Questions: What should you focus on instead of forecasts according to Lynch?
Answers: Lynch recommends concentrating on what's actually happening to the companies you've invested in rather than macro predictions.

Questions: What is Lynch's research success ratio?
Answers: Lynch teaches that if you study 10 companies, you'll find 1 with a better story than expected. Study 50, you'll find 5.

Questions: What happens when you don't research companies according to Lynch?
Answers: Lynch warns that not studying companies gives you same success as playing poker without looking at your cards.

Questions: What is Lynch's example of patience being rewarded?
Answers: Lynch notes even missing Wal-Mart in first five years, it was still great to own in the next five years.

Questions: When does time work against investors according to Lynch?
Answers: Lynch warns time is against you when you own options due to their expiration dates.

Questions: What does Lynch warn about frequent mutual fund switching?
Answers: Lynch notes the capital-gains tax penalizes investors who do too much switching between mutual funds.

Questions: How does Lynch rank the U.S. stock market globally?
Answers: Lynch notes the U.S. market ranks eighth among major world markets in total return over the past decade.

Questions: What does Lynch guarantee about long-term stock vs. bond performance?
Answers: Lynch states a portfolio of well-chosen stocks and/or equity mutual funds will always outperform bonds or money-market accounts long-term.

Questions: What warning does Lynch give about poorly chosen stocks?
Answers: Lynch warns that a portfolio of poorly chosen stocks won't outperform money left under the mattress - selection quality matters.

Questions: Why did Lynch get his hair cut at Supercuts?
Answers: A prospectus for the haircutting venture had found its way to his desk, leading him to cheat on his regular barber Vinnie DiVincenzo for research purposes.

Questions: Who is Lynch's regular barber and what does he charge?
Answers: Vinnie DiVincenzo offers a $10 haircut with pleasant conversation at his Marblehead, Massachusetts business.

Questions: Where was the Supercuts location Lynch visited?
Answers: 829 Boylston Street, Boston, on the second floor of a brownstone.

Questions: How did Supercuts prices compare to Lynch's regular barber?
Answers: Prices were in line with Vinnie's charges and substantially less than beauty salons and unisex outlets where his family gets haircuts.

Questions: What did Lynch observe about customer demand at Supercuts?
Answers: Three customers getting haircuts, four waiting, all male, indicating people thought a Supercuts haircut was worth waiting for.

Questions: How does Lynch compare Supercuts to Service Corporation International?
Answers: Similar situation - people were dying at regular rate, somebody had to bury them, industry made up of inefficient small operators whose children wanted to go to law school.

Questions: What did Lynch learn about haircutter licensing requirements?
Answers: Haircutters have to be licensed (unlike fund managers), and there are no requirements for managing billions but you need to pass a test to trim sideburns.

Questions: What concerned Lynch about Supercuts' balance sheet?
Answers: Debt was 31% of total capital, a disturbing number that required further explanation.

Questions: What was Lynch's personal experience getting the Supercut?
Answers: The stylist snipped off everything including his sideburns so quickly he had no time to object, feeling like the privet hedge in Edward Scissorhands.

Questions: How did Lynch's family react to his new haircut?
Answers: What happened to you?' from his wife and daughters, with acquaintances saying he looked 'young' (which Lynch took as diplomatic politeness).

Questions: What is Lynch's exception to the 'like the store, buy the stock' rule?
Answers: After being sheared at Supercuts, he liked the stock prospects far more than he liked the store experience.

Questions: Who did Lynch speak with at Supercuts corporate?
Answers: Steven J. Thompson, senior vice-president and CFO, who commiserated about the lost sideburns and discussed business fundamentals.

Questions: What was Supercuts' growth rate and valuation when Lynch recommended it?
Answers: 20% grower selling for 16 times earnings at time of recommendation.

Questions: What did Lynch tell the Barron's panel about his Supercuts experience?
Answers: I got a haircut there, I tried it out.' When asked if it was his current haircut, he admitted it was.

Questions: What was Alan Abelson's reaction to Lynch's Supercuts haircut?
Answers: We won't advertise that' - referring to Lynch's appearance after the Supercuts experience.

Questions: What convinced Lynch to recommend Supercuts despite his bad haircut?
Answers: The excellent numbers and business fundamentals won out over the lost sideburns and poor personal experience.

Questions: What does Lynch emphasize about the haircutting industry transformation?
Answers: A perfect opportunity for a well-managed, efficient nationwide franchise to capture market from disappearing independent operators.

Questions: How does Lynch view the Supercuts business model sustainability?
Answers: Unlike aluminum industry where half earnings go to plant improvements, hair salon's biggest ongoing expenses are just scissors and combs.

Questions: What was Lynch's promise after the Supercuts experience?
Answers: Never again to stray from Vinnie DiVincenzo and his regular $10 haircut - loyalty to his regular barber was restored.

Questions: What is Lynch's preference between great industries and lousy industries?
Answers: Lynch prefers lousy industries over great industries anytime - in lousy industries, the weak drop out and survivors get bigger market share.

Questions: What does Lynch say about popular vs. unpopular industries?
Answers: A great industry that's growing fast attracts too much attention and competitors - as Yogi Berra said, 'It's so popular, nobody goes there anymore.'

Questions: What correlation does Lynch observe about corporate culture and performance?
Answers: Pompous boardrooms, overblown executive salaries, demoralized rank and file, excessive debt, and mediocre performance go hand in hand.

Questions: Who recommended Sun Television & Appliances to Lynch?
Answers: John Weiss, an analyst from Montgomery Securities in California, after Lynch asked about discount appliance store chains.

Questions: What convinced Lynch to call Sun TV directly?
Answers: Weiss's compelling story led Lynch to call corporate headquarters in Ohio to talk to the source directly.

Questions: Who did Lynch reach at Sun TV and what does this indicate?
Answers: Bob Oyster, the CEO, without delay - indicating the company doesn't suffer from excessive hierarchy.

Questions: What demographic fact does Lynch mention about Columbus?
Answers: 50% of U.S. population lives within 500 miles of Columbus, and it's the only major city east of Mississippi, north of Mason-Dixon that grew 1950-1990.

Questions: What were Sun TV's financial metrics when Lynch analyzed it?
Answers: Less than $10 million debt, stock selling for $18 with P/E ratio of 15, while growing at 25-30% rate.

Questions: What are the characteristics of Lynch's Magnificent Seven companies?
Answers: Great companies in lousy industries that have shown exceptional performance despite challenging sector conditions.

Questions: How does Lynch suggest judging a company's commitment to frugality?
Answers: Visit the headquarters - if company has a big building, it doesn't mean people are smart, but it means you helped pay for it.

Questions: What does Lynch find less exciting than Bandag's business?
Answers: What could be less exciting than a company that makes retread tires in Muscatine, Iowa?

Questions: What does Crown Cork & Seal remind Lynch of?
Answers: New England Wire & Cable from 'Other People's Money' - messy executive suite over factory decorated with muffler-shop calendars.

Questions: What are Lynch's three basic types of S&Ls?
Answers: The bad guys (perpetrated fraud), the greedy guys (ruined a good thing), and the Jimmy Stewarts (quietly profitable all along).

Questions: How did Lynch approach S&L investing during this period?
Answers: He was so indiscriminate that he bought anything with 'first' or 'trust' in the name, investing in 135 of 145 thrifts whose prospectuses reached his desk.

Questions: What were Lynch's two explanations for his S&L attraction?
Answers: 1) Fund was so big and S&Ls so small he needed large quantities like whales surviving on plankton, 2) Unique way S&Ls came public made them automatic bargains.

Questions: What publication did Lynch use for S&L research?
Answers: The Thrift Digest, published by SNL Securities, thick as Boston phone directory, costs $700/year for monthly updates.

Questions: What are the key factors in Lynch's S&L scorecard?
Answers: Current price, initial offering price, equity-to-assets ratio, dividend, book value, P/E ratio, high-risk real estate assets, 90-day nonperforming assets, real estate owned.

Questions: What E/A ratio does Lynch prefer before investing?
Answers: At least 7.5% E/A ratio for disaster protection and because high E/A makes attractive takeover candidate.

Questions: How many S&Ls did Lynch end up recommending in Barron's?
Answers: Seven S&Ls: five strong Jimmy Stewart types and two long shots (born-agains) coming back from Chapter 11 edge.

Questions: Why did Lynch pick two 'born-again' S&Ls despite poor numbers?
Answers: They maintained high E/A ratios despite problems, giving leeway to work out troubles, and stock prices had fallen so low that survival meant big gains.

Questions: What is an example of Lynch's bottom-fishing approach?
Answers: Lawrence Savings fell from $13 to 75 cents - if it survived, bottom fishers would make substantial money.

Questions: Why does Lynch usually call companies before investing?
Answers: To improve odds by finding specific information or fishing for surprises that haven't come to Wall Street analysts' attention.

Questions: How many S&Ls did Lynch call for his detailed research?
Answers: Six S&Ls: four strong ones plus two born-agains (he didn't call Eagle Financial because annual report arrived in time).

Questions: When did Lynch call Glacier Bancorp and what was he wearing?
Answers: Day after Christmas, wearing plaid pants and sweatshirt in the empty Fidelity building except for security guard.

Questions: Why does Lynch prefer antiquated names over trendy ones?
Answers: He'd rather have antiquated and parochial than trendy and sophisticated, which usually means desperate to improve image.

Questions: What is Lynch's concern about 'bancorp' vs 'bank' names?
Answers: He knows what a bank is, but 'bancorp' makes him nervous - prefers companies that stick to business and let images take care of themselves.

Questions: How does Lynch establish rapport before asking serious questions?
Answers: Started with mountains, mentioned family trips to Western states and national parks, discussed timber industry, spotted owl, ski areas.

Questions: What was Lynch's concern about Glacier's 9.2% commercial loans?
Answers: In New England that would be scary, but Montana wasn't Massachusetts - mostly multifamily housing in growing area with California escapees.

Questions: What did Lynch find in Germantown's balance sheet analysis?
Answers: Deposits up (customers keeping money there), loans down (bankers being conservative), investment securities up $50M (parking assets in bonds).

Questions: How did Lynch learn about Sovereign Bancorp?
Answers: Through November 25, 1991 Barron's article entitled 'Hometown Lender to the Well-Heeled' about serving wealthy southeastern Pennsylvania.

Questions: Why does Lynch prefer share buybacks over acquisitions for enhancing value?
Answers: Share buybacks are simplest, most direct way to reward shareholders, while companies often squander money on fanciful acquisitions instead.

Questions: What examples does Lynch give of successful buyback strategies?
Answers: International Dairy Queen and Crown Cork & Seal became spectacular performers because management committed to buying back shares - that's how Teledyne became 100-bagger.

Questions: How does Lynch analyze long-shot S&Ls?
Answers: Find equity amount, compare to commercial loans outstanding, assume the worst - if half go bad, does S&L survive?

Questions: What is the 'can't-lose proposition' Lynch describes about S&L IPOs?
Answers: Like buying a house and finding former owners left your down payment money in kitchen drawer with note 'Keep this, it belonged to you anyway.'

Questions: What examples does Lynch give of outstanding 1992 mutual thrift performance?
Answers: Mutual Savings Bank of Bay City, Michigan and United Postal Bancorp in St. Louis both quadrupled in value.

Questions: What is Lynch's advice about participating in local S&L conversions?
Answers: Open savings account in any mutual savings bank in your area to get right to participate in IPO when it happens.

Questions: Why does Lynch welcome the MLP paperwork requirement?
Answers: The nuisance dissuades many investors, particularly fund managers, keeping prices down and creating bargains.

Questions: What is appealing about MLP names according to Lynch?
Answers: Names seem antiquated and out of sync with high-tech culture - Cedar Fair could be from Thackeray, Green Acres from Jane Austen.

Questions: What brought EQK Green Acres to Lynch's attention?
Answers: The stock dropped during Saddam Sell-off from $13.75 high to $9.75, offering 13.5% yield - as good as junk bonds but more secure.

Questions: What was Lynch's key concern about any mall investment?
Answers: Vacancies - malls averaged 4% vacancy rate while Green Acres was lower.

Questions: What warning sign did Lynch see in Green Acres' third-quarter 1991 report?
Answers: Company was debating whether to pay regular quarterly dividend increase of one cent to save $100,000 - breaking 13-quarter string for paltry savings.

Questions: Why didn't Lynch recommend Green Acres for a second time?
Answers: Potential agreements weren't signed contracts - he preferred waiting for proof rather than buying on rumors.

Questions: What did Lynch ask about Cedar Fair's 1992 prospects?
Answers: He looks for reasons next year will be better than last - if he can't find such reason, he questions why own the stock.

Questions: What evidence did Lynch see of management dedication?
Answers: President was in office taking phone calls on December 23, two days before Christmas.

Questions: How did Lynch determine Sun was a low-cost operator?
Answers: Gross margin of 60% (dividing cost of sales by net sales) - making $40 profit on every $100 of sales, tops among distributors.

Questions: How did Sun's debt situation affect Lynch's analysis?
Answers: High debt (60% of capitalization) was concerning, but cash flow sufficient to cover interest four times over.

Questions: Why didn't Lynch dismiss Tenera completely?
Answers: Zero debt and no large expenses meant it wasn't going out of business immediately, had well-regarded nuclear services division.

Questions: What were Tenera's positives for Lynch's analysis?
Answers: Zero debt, no capital spending needed (consultants need desk, calculator, phone), earning power of 77-81 cents/share in prior four years.

Questions: How did Lynch value Tenera as potential liquidation?
Answers: Figured auction value worth more than $1.50/share with no debts, entire amount minus legal fees would go to shareholders.

Questions: What convinced Lynch that Tenera had remaining value?
Answers: Insiders were holding onto shares and new management believed turnaround was possible within reasonable timeframe.

Questions: What led Lynch to Phelps Dodge in 1992?
Answers: He was foiled in housing rebound plays by other buyers, but they hadn't anticipated copper market rebound - his plumber confirmed copper pipe prices rising.

Questions: What makes copper more valuable than aluminum according to Lynch?
Answers: Aluminum is 8% of earth's crust and easy to extract; copper is scarcer and vanishing asset - mines run out or flood and close.

Questions: How did Lynch evaluate Phelps Dodge's subsidiary businesses?
Answers: Carbon black OK, magnet wire OK, truck wheels OK, Canyon Resources gold mine could become big moneymaker.

Questions: What technique does Lynch use for valuing diversified companies?
Answers: Thumbnail appraisal of various divisions - take earnings of each division, multiply by generic P/E ratio to get rough value.

Questions: Why does Lynch classify autos as cyclicals rather than blue chips?
Answers: Buying auto stock for 25 years is like flying over Alps - you may get something, but not as much as the hiker experiencing ups and downs.

Questions: What convinced Lynch to look at autos again in 1991?
Answers: Auto stocks down 50% from recent highs, widespread showroom gloom, but certain that Americans will continue replacing cars.

Questions: What is Lynch's certainty about American car buying habits?
Answers: Until someone invents reliable Hovercraft for home use, cars will continue being America's most beloved personal possession.

Questions: What forces eventual car replacement according to Lynch?
Answers: Cars eventually need replacement due to being tired of old ones, brakes shot, road visible through rusted floorboards, plus mandatory inspections.

Questions: What was the car sales decline that led to Lynch's 1980s auto investment?
Answers: Annual sales declined from 15.4 million vehicles (1977) to 10.5 million (1982), but couldn't go to zero.

Questions: What is the key indicator Lynch uses for auto stock timing?
Answers: Used-car prices - when dealers lower prices, new car market is worse; when used prices rise, good times ahead for automakers.

Questions: Why did Lynch favor Chrysler, Ford, and Volvo over General Motors?
Answers: GM's reputation for excellence far exceeded desire to live up to it - company was arrogant, myopic, resting on laurels.

Questions: What was Lynch's experience with GM's investor relations?
Answers: Assigned to investor relations guy who couldn't find R&D center (size of big college campus) - took couple hours to locate it.

Questions: How did Lynch view GM in 1991 compared to earlier opinions?
Answers: Previous popular view: powerful company with profitable future. 1991 popular view: weak company with miserable future - Lynch suspected latest view equally misguided.

Questions: What parallel does Lynch draw between GM 1992 and Chrysler 1982?
Answers: Same story: powerful enterprise forgets how to make cars, loses public confidence, lays off thousands, heads for has-been scrap heap.

Questions: What gives Lynch confidence in GM's potential recovery?
Answers: Better balance sheet in 1992 than Chrysler had in 1982, plus profitable non-auto divisions.

Questions: What examples does Lynch give of big utility winners in recent years?
Answers: Southern Company ($11 to $33 in 5 years), Oklahoma Gas and Electric ($13 to $40), Philadelphia Electric ($9 to $26).

Questions: When did Lynch have 10% of Magellan invested in utilities?
Answers: During brief periods when interest rates were declining and economy was sputtering - he treated utilities as interest-rate cyclicals.

Questions: Which utilities has Lynch done best with?
Answers: The troubled ones: General Public Utilities (Three Mile Island), Public Service of New Hampshire, Long Island Lighting, Gulf States, Middle South (now Entergy).

Questions: Why is Lynch's record better with troubled utilities than troubled companies generally?
Answers: Utilities are regulated by government - as long as people need electricity, a way must be found for utility to continue functioning.

Questions: Who identified the 'troubled utility cycle' that Lynch references?
Answers: Three analysts at NatWest Investment Banking Group: Kathleen Lally, John Kellenyi, and Philip Smyth.

Questions: What is Lynch's strategy for investing in troubled utilities?
Answers: Buy on omission of dividend and wait for good news, or buy when first good news arrives in second stage.

Questions: What simple strategy does Lynch suggest for troubled utilities?
Answers: Buy when dividend is omitted, hold until dividend is restored - strategy with terrific success ratio.

Questions: Who brought CMS to Lynch's attention?
Answers: Danny Frank, manager of Fidelity's Special Situations Fund, who had investigated several troubled nukes.

Questions: How did Lynch verify CMS could handle its debt load?
Answers: Calculated cash flow of $6/share (earnings plus depreciation divided by shares), sufficient to pay interest with money left over.

Questions: What could CMS do with its excess cash according to Lynch?
Answers: Buy back stock, make acquisitions, or increase dividend - all benefiting shareholders.

Questions: Why did Lynch view CMS as more than just regulatory gamble?
Answers: Powerful cash flow would enable reentry to strong utility ranks regardless of commission decisions.

Questions: What alternatives does Lynch mention for distressed utility investing?
Answers: Public Service Company of New Mexico or 'more hapless' Tucson Electric, both with available investor relations staff.

Questions: What is Lynch's attitude toward government garage sales?
Answers: When Uncle Sam or the Queen of England is having a garage sale, Lynch always tries to attend.

Questions: What British privatization did Lynch encounter at Fidelity?
Answers: British contingent with numbered prospectus for water utilities: Northumbrian Water, Severn Trent, Yorkshire Water, Welsh Water PLC.

Questions: What other U.S. privatization possibilities has Lynch considered?
Answers: Amtrak, naval petroleum reserves in California and Wyoming, National Gallery, Marine Band, Niagara Falls.

Questions: What tangible result of Allied Capital investment does Lynch mention?
Answers: Air purifier in his bedroom that removes so much grit the room has air quality of genetic engineering lab.

Questions: What was Allied Capital II's dividend and price when Lynch analyzed it?
Answers: Selling for $19 with 6% dividend.

Questions: How does Lynch view Allied Capital II as an investment opportunity?
Answers: Simple way to turn S&L fiasco into something advantageous - chance to make back some taxes paid for S&L bailout.

Questions: Which group on Wall Street did Lynch miss for several years?
Answers: The mutual fund industry - he missed Dreyfus, Franklin Resources, Colonial Group, T. Rowe Price, State Street Bank, Alliance Capital Management, and Eaton Vance.

Questions: How does Lynch compare himself to a mall manager regarding mutual fund stocks?
Answers: Like the mall manager who neglected to buy Gap stock despite seeing sales results daily, Lynch neglected mutual fund companies despite being in the industry.

Questions: What what-if portfolio performance does Lynch present for mutual fund companies?
Answers: If you divided money equally among eight stocks from beginning 1988 to end 1989, you would have outperformed 99% of the funds these companies promote.

Questions: What is Lynch's observation about the Gold Rush and mutual fund investing?
Answers: In the Gold Rush, people who sold picks and shovels did better than the prospectors - during fund popularity, investing in fund companies beats their products.

Questions: How did Lynch perform with mutual fund stock recommendations in 1991?
Answers: Failed to recommend a single mutual fund company, missing Franklin (75% gain), Dreyfus (55%), T. Rowe Price (116%), UAM (80%).

Questions: Which fund-related stock did Lynch recommend in 1991 and how did it perform?
Answers: Kemper (insurance with fund business via $50 billion managed) - stock doubled in 1991.

Questions: Who did Lynch speak with at Colonial Group?
Answers: Corporate treasurer Davey Scoon on January 3, who reported business improvement especially in muni bond funds.

Questions: What mistake did Lynch make with his mother-in-law regarding State Street?
Answers: Advised her to sell when money-market assets seemed declining because she'd doubled her money - stock has tripled again since then.

Questions: What does Lynch say about restaurant stock recommendations in 1992?
Answers: He didn't recommend any restaurant stocks in 1992, but admits he should have.

Questions: What happened to Taco Bell after Lynch discovered it?
Answers: Rebounded to $40, then acquired by PepsiCo, which likes to own food companies because they help sell Pepsi's soft drinks.

Questions: What 1980s restaurant opportunities does Lynch mention?
Answers: Cracker Barrel (popular gift shop, delicious seafood and biscuits), Chili's (public 1984), Sbarro (1985), Ryan's Family Steak Houses (1982), Uno Restaurants (1987).

Questions: What is the tale of two hamburger franchises Lynch tells?
Answers: Chili's (Dallas) vs. Fuddrucker's (San Antonio) - both featured gourmet burger and distinctive surroundings.

Questions: Where did Lynch spot Au Bon Pain?
Answers: In the Burlington Mall - started in Boston in 1977, went public in 1991 at $10/share.

Questions: What is Lynch's preference between high-tech investments and food?
Answers: If choice between state-of-the-art computer chip and state-of-the-art bagel, he'll take the bagel any time.

Questions: Why didn't Lynch recommend Au Bon Pain initially?
Answers: Stock had doubled to carry P/E ratio of 40 based on expected 1992 earnings.

Questions: At what point would Lynch back up the truck on Au Bon Pain?
Answers: When price fell to $14 (less than 20x 1993 earnings) - any 25% grower selling for 20x earnings is a buy.

Questions: What examples does Lynch give of buy-and-forget dangers?
Answers: Investors who bought and forgot IBM, Sears, and Eastman Kodak are sorry they did - these stocks declined significantly over time.

Questions: What is the six-month checkup according to Lynch?
Answers: Not simply looking up stock price in newspaper, but following the stories to get answers to two basic questions.

Questions: How did Lynch's 21 Barron's selections perform in the first six months?
Answers: The portfolio increased 19.2% while the S&P 500 returned only 1.64% - extremely well in a so-so market.

Questions: What is Lynch's view on paying 20 times earnings for a 25% grower?
Answers: He doesn't mind it, especially when entire NYSE was selling at 20x earnings for companies growing at only 8-10% rate.

Questions: How does Lynch categorize Body Shop's growth phase?
Answers: Attractive mid-life phase - second decade of 30 years of growth.

Questions: What was Lynch's earnings projection for Pier 1?
Answers: 80 cents from own stores plus 10-15 cents from revived Sunbelt Nursery = $1/share, making it $14 stock at reasonable 14x P/E.

Questions: What positives kept General Host as a hold for Lynch?
Answers: Strong cash flow, dividend raised 14th year in a row, stock selling below book value, expansion proceeding as planned.

Questions: Who had bought General Host stock according to Lynch's research?
Answers: Mario Gabelli had bought million shares for his value-oriented fund.

Questions: What happened to Sunbelt Nursery after Lynch's recommendation?
Answers: Lost money since January due to more rain in Southwest dampening gardening enthusiasm.

Questions: Why did Lynch prefer Calloway's over Sunbelt by the checkup?
Answers: Calloway's also fell in half due to rain, but was best company in industry with better fundamentals.

Questions: What is Lynch's principle about investing within attractive groups?
Answers: Find the undervalued stock within attractive group - technique he's often employed with good results.

Questions: What overhang problem did Lynch discover with Supercuts?
Answers: Carlton Investments (part of bankrupt Drexel Burnham Lambert) owns 2.2 million shares that creditors will demand be sold.

Questions: What was Lynch's concern about Supercuts expansion?
Answers: 80-100 new franchises planned for 1993 - he's seen promising franchises ruined by overeager expansion.

Questions: What advice did Lynch give to Supercuts CEO?
Answers: If you have choice between reaching your goal in fifteen years or five years, fifteen is better.'

Questions: What is the key to making money in stocks according to Lynch?
Answers: The key to making money in stocks is not to get scared out of them. This point cannot be overemphasized.

Questions: How long has Lynch participated in the Barron's Roundtable?
Answers: Lynch has participated in the Barron's Roundtable every year since 1986.

Questions: What does Lynch say about weekend worrying?
Answers: Weekend worrying is dangerous for investors because they have extra time to ponder distressing news, leading to emotional decisions that spoil nest eggs.

Questions: What extreme behavior did Lynch observe in 1990?
Answers: He heard cabdrivers recommending bonds and barbers bragging about buying 'puts' (options that increase in value as stocks decline).

Questions: What were some of the pessimistic headlines Lynch collected from fall 1990?
Answers: Layoffs Hit Professional Ranks,' 'How Safe Is Your Job?,' 'The Real Estate Bust,' 'Housing Slump Hammering Remodelers,' 'Can Your Bank Stay Afloat?'

Questions: What was Lynch doing personally during the pessimistic predictions?
Answers: Lynch was actually buying stocks, adding to holdings in his personal account and for charitable trusts, increasing stakes in W.R. Grace and Morrison-Knudsen.

Questions: What does Lynch say about preparing for total disaster?
Answers: It's beyond him why investors bail out of best investments to prepare for total disaster - if disaster strikes, cash will be as useless as stock certificates.

Questions: What is the Even Bigger Picture according to Lynch?
Answers: Over 70 years, stocks have provided 11% annual gains while Treasury bills, bonds, and CDs returned less than half that amount.

Questions: What does Lynch identify as the main factor keeping people away from stocks?
Answers: The cultural memory of the 1929 Crash, which continues to scare people 60 years later, including people who weren't even born in 1929.

Questions: How does Lynch compare market declines to Minnesota weather?
Answers: A decline in stocks is as normal as frigid air in Minnesota - you expect it, prepare for it, and know that warmer weather will return.

Questions: How did Lynch prepare Magellan shareholders for inevitable setbacks?
Answers: In annual reports, he often reminded shareholders that such setbacks were inevitable and normal parts of market cycles.

Questions: What comfort does Lynch find in the story of 40 market declines?
Answers: The story continues to comfort him during gloomy periods when there's another chance to buy great companies at bargain prices.

Questions: What type of faith does Lynch say stockpickers need?
Answers: Faith that America will survive, people will keep getting up and putting on pants, and corporations making pants will profit for shareholders.

Questions: What is Lynch's view on American workers and entrepreneurs?
Answers: Lynch has faith that America is a nation of hardworking and inventive people, and that even yuppies have gotten a bad rap for being lazy.

Questions: How many mutual funds existed when Lynch wrote this book?
Answers: There were 3,565 mutual funds: 1,266 equity funds, 1,457 bond and income funds, 566 taxable money-market funds, and 276 short-term municipal bond funds.

Questions: What is Lynch's simple strategy for Wall Street success?
Answers: Buy stocks from Moody's Dividend Achievers list and stick with them as long as they stay on the list.

Questions: What advice does Lynch give about stock allocation?
Answers: Increase the stock part of the mix to the limit of your tolerance for the best long-term results.

Questions: What was the bond/stock mix Lynch's nonprofit organization had before restructuring?
Answers: 50% stocks and 50% bonds, yielding about 6% return with 4% growth rate - barely enough to keep up with inflation.

Questions: What does Lynch's radical conclusion suggest about bonds for income?
Answers: Theoretically, it makes no sense to put any money into bonds, even if you need income - you're better off with stocks even when dipping into capital.

Questions: What does Lynch say about government bond funds?
Answers: He can't figure out why anyone would invest in intermediate or long-term government bond funds when they could buy Treasury bonds directly with no fees.

Questions: What is Lynch's advice about past performance charts?
Answers: Don't spend a lot of time poring over past performance charts - it's better to stick with steady, consistent performers than move in and out trying to catch waves.

Questions: Why is Lynch getting interested in gold sector again?
Answers: Gold supply from new mines running out, decade of low prices discouraged exploration, demand increasing (especially China factor), potential inflation hedge.

Questions: What example does Lynch give of country fund overenthusiasm?
Answers: Germany Fund was bid up 25% above underlying stock values as Berlin Wall fell, then sold at 20-25% discount when reality set in.

Questions: What is Lynch's view on U.S. vs foreign companies?
Answers: The U.S. still has the best companies and system for investing - Europe lacks growth companies, information is sketchy, earnings estimates are unreliable.

Questions: What does Lynch say about Japanese superiority claims?
Answers: It's malarkey - Japan is the richest country where people have trouble making ends meet, with $5 apples, $100 dinners, and $1 million, 1000-square-foot homes.

Questions: What was the problem with the Japanese market according to Lynch?
Answers: It was subject to behind-the-scenes manipulation unknown since the 1920s, with money-back guarantees from brokers and controlled stock prices.

Questions: What does Lynch recommend for mutual fund strategies?
Answers: Put as much money into stock funds as possible, know what kinds you own, divide among 3-4 types, add money to lagging sectors, stick with solid performers.

Questions: What was Lynch doing when Magellan was launched in 1965?
Answers: Lynch was a student at Boston College, caddying golf games on weekends.

Questions: How did Lynch's mother get involved in mutual funds?
Answers: A schoolteacher moonlighting as a fund salesman convinced her to buy Fidelity Capital because 'a Chinese guy' (Gerry Tsai) was running it.

Questions: What was Lynch's situation when he took over Magellan in 1977?
Answers: $18 million in assets, $50 million tax-loss carryforward, terrible stock market, declining customers, and the fund was closed to new buyers.

Questions: What does Lynch say about being brought along slowly as a fund manager?
Answers: The obscurity for the first four years was a blessing, enabling him to learn and make mistakes without being in a spotlight.

Questions: What was Lynch's background before managing Magellan?
Answers: He was director of research at Fidelity from 1974-1977, served on the investment committee, and had begun helping a Boston charity manage its portfolio in 1975.

Questions: What was Lynch's first stock pick that he missed as a 30-bagger?
Answers: General Cinema, which was selling for less than $1 when he visited on October 12, 1977, and went to over $30.

Questions: What were Lynch's biggest positions by December 1977?
Answers: Congoleum (51,000 shares worth $833,000), Transamerica, Union Oil, and Aetna Life and Casualty.

Questions: How did Lynch discover Hanes stock?
Answers: Through his wife Carolyn, who was crazy about their L'eggs pantyhose product.

Questions: What was Lynch's reaction when he first ordered Taco Bell stock?
Answers: His trader Charlie Maxfield asked 'What's that, the Mexican telephone company?' showing how unknown the company was.

Questions: What attracted Lynch to Congoleum?
Answers: It had invented seamless vinyl flooring that could be rolled out like carpet, and was building naval frigates using modular prefab techniques.

Questions: Why did Lynch like Taco Bell initially?
Answers: Tasty tacos, 90% of country not yet exposed to them, good record, strong balance sheet, and home office that resembled a neighborhood garage.

Questions: What was Magellan's performance in Lynch's first 12 months?
Answers: The fund was up 20% while the Dow Jones average lost 17.6% and S&P 500 lost 9.4% in the same period.

Questions: How did Lynch describe his early strategy in 1978?
Answers: Reduced holdings in autos, aerospace, railroads, pollution, utilities, chemicals, electronics, energy; added to financial institutions, broadcasting, entertainment, insurance, banking, consumer products, lodging, leasing.'

Questions: Did Lynch have an overall strategy when he started?
Answers: No, Lynch never had an overall strategy. His stockpicking was entirely empirical, going from case to case like a bloodhound following a scent.

Questions: How did Lynch's approach differ from growth fund managers?
Answers: As a capital appreciation fund manager, he could buy anything when growth sectors were overvalued, while growth fund managers were forced into overpriced inventory.

Questions: What was Lynch's turnover rate in the early years?
Answers: 343% in the first year with 41 stocks, and 300% in each of the three years thereafter - a very high trading pace.

Questions: Why was Lynch trading so frequently in the early years?
Answers: He was constantly selling to raise cash for redemptions while discovering new prospects, and had to sell something to buy something new in the small fund.

Questions: What does Lynch mean by 'pulling out the flowers and watering the weeds'?
Answers: Selling winning stocks too early while holding onto losing stocks - a common and expensive mistake he made early on.

Questions: Which great stocks did Lynch sell too early?
Answers: Albertson's (300-bagger), Toys 'R' Us, Pic 'N' Save, Warner Communications, Federal Express ($5 to $70 in two years), and Home Depot.

Questions: How did Lynch learn about companies in his early years?
Answers: He visited dozens at headquarters, attended regional investment conferences, and companies came to Fidelity for lunches, breakfasts, and dinners.

Questions: What was Lynch's monthly rule for industry contact?
Answers: Once a month he tried to have at least one conversation with a representative of each major industry group as an early-warning system.

Questions: What question did Lynch always ask at the end of company meetings?
Answers: Which of your competitors do you respect the most? When a CEO admits a rival is doing better, it's a powerful endorsement.

Questions: What does Lynch say about being lied to in corporate meetings?
Answers: In thousands of encounters, he was lied to only a handful of times - there may be fewer liars on Wall Street than Main Street.

Questions: Why are there fewer liars on Wall Street according to Lynch?
Answers: Financial types are so widely distrusted that every claim is reviewed by the SEC, so they aren't allowed to lie, and lies can't survive quarterly earnings reports.

Questions: How did Lynch learn about the insurance industry?
Answers: Through crash courses from executives at Aetna, Travelers, and Connecticut General in Hartford over a couple of days.

Questions: What was Lynch's insurance allocation in March 1980?
Answers: 25.4% of the fund was in property or casualty underwriters, making him insurance's best friend.

Questions: How did Lynch discover the potential in bank stocks?
Answers: At a Robinson-Humphrey conference in Atlanta, he took a side trip to visit First Atlanta, which had 12 years of continuously higher earnings.

Questions: What impressed Lynch about regional banks?
Answers: First Atlanta had earnings greater than the sales of many flashy companies, yet solid banks were selling for half the P/E ratio of the market.

Questions: Which banks does Lynch show as examples of great performance?
Answers: Wachovia (10-fold increase in 10 years), Norwest of Minneapolis, and NBD Bancorp of Detroit - all looking like fast-growth company charts.

Questions: Why are regional banks mispriced according to Lynch?
Answers: Banks growing at 15% like Pep Boys or Dunkin' Donuts get low P/E multiples, treated like mature utilities instead of growth companies.

Questions: What was Lynch's bond strategy in early 1982?
Answers: With Treasury bonds paying 13-14%, Lynch made them his biggest position because yields exceeded normal stock returns.

Questions: Why doesn't Lynch recommend preparing for total disaster?
Answers: If total disaster strikes, cash will be as useless as stock certificates, but if it doesn't (more likely), the 'cautious' become reckless by selling valuable assets.

Questions: How did Lynch approach the 1982 recession fears?
Answers: He focused on the Even Bigger Picture, assumed the worst wouldn't happen, and asked what would happen if it didn't - leading him to both stocks and bonds.

Questions: What led Lynch to Chrysler in March 1982?
Answers: He got interested in Ford as an auto rebound play, and talking to Ford convinced him Chrysler would benefit even more.

Questions: What convinced Lynch that Chrysler could survive?
Answers: The company had capacity to survive at least a couple of years, the government had guaranteed loans, and the entire industry was due for a rebound.

Questions: What new products excited Lynch about Chrysler's future?
Answers: The Dodge Daytona, Chrysler Laser, G-124 Turbo Car, convertibles, sportier New Yorker, and especially the T-115 minivan.

Questions: What time did Lynch's working day begin?
Answers: Lynch's working day began at 6:05 A.M. when he met his carpool ride with radiologists Jeff and Bobbie Moore.

Questions: What was Lynch doing during his carpool ride?
Answers: Lynch sat in the back with a small light, perusing annual reports and chart books, while Bobbie held X-rays up to a light in the front seat.

Questions: What time did Lynch arrive at the office?
Answers: By 6:45 A.M., but he wasn't alone - Fidelity was full of analysts and fund managers who arrived before dawn.

Questions: What were Lynch's 'sophisticated tools of the trade'?
Answers: The S&P stock guide (free from brokers), antique Rolodex, empty yellow legal pads, 2Â½ pencils, and clunky Sharp calculator with oversize buttons.

Questions: Why did Lynch prefer the old Quotron system?
Answers: The blank screen was better because you couldn't stare at it all day watching stocks go up and down - he had to turn off the newer versions.

Questions: What did Lynch do in the precious morning hours before market opened?
Answers: Reviewed buy/sell summaries from the day before, read in-house analyst reports, read Wall Street Journal, and wrote out new buy/sell lists.

Questions: Who were Lynch's head traders?
Answers: Barry Lyden handled buys, and later Carlene DeLuca was assigned to handle sells, both very patient with Lynch's extensive trading lists.

Questions: How much time did Lynch spend on trading?
Answers: About an hour a day instead of 10 minutes - he admits he should have used the extra 50 minutes to call two more companies.

Questions: What is Lynch's key insight about successful investing?
Answers: Focus on the companies, not on the stocks - this is one of the keys to successful investing.

Questions: How did Lynch keep track of his company contacts?
Answers: He wrote down the name of everyone he met and kept detailed notes in loose-leaf binders with company names, stock prices, and story summaries.

Questions: Why did Lynch avoid the lobby when going to the bathroom?
Answers: Corporate guests and analysts waited there, and he'd have to waste time on small talk or snub friends, so he snuck down a back stairway.

Questions: Who was Lynch's first assistant and what happened to him?
Answers: Rich Fentin set the standard for quality and went on to run the Fidelity Growth and Fidelity Puritan funds.

Questions: What other successful fund managers came from Lynch's assistant program?
Answers: Danny Frank (Special Situations), George Noble (Overseas Fund), Bob Stansky (Growth), Will Danoff (Contrafund), and Jeff Vinik (later ran Magellan).

Questions: What advantage did Lynch have as a capital appreciation fund manager?
Answers: He had the widest latitude to buy stocks recommended by special situations, small-stock, growth, value, and over-the-counter specialists.

Questions: What was Lynch's innovation with the kitchen timer?
Answers: He pretended to set it at three minutes for presentations but actually shortened it to 90 seconds to keep discussions focused.

Questions: What was Lynch's approach to feedback at presentations?
Answers: No feedback was allowed - listeners could follow up on leads or ignore them, focusing on idea quality rather than speaker quality.

Questions: How did Lynch evaluate outside analysts?
Answers: He was selective, noting great variation in quality and preferring analysts who called companies regularly and visited them in person.

Questions: Who were some of Lynch's trusted outside analysts?
Answers: Maggie Gilliam at First Boston (Home Depot, Limited), John Kellenyi at NatWest (utilities), Elliot Schneider at Gruntal (financial services).

Questions: What made certain analysts valuable to Lynch?
Answers: Analysts who reinforced opinions with multiple reports as stocks rose, not just initial buy signals that were quickly forgotten.

Questions: How did Lynch's patience change by 1981?
Answers: He became more patient, redemptions were down so he wasn't forced to sell for cash, and turnover dropped from 300% to 110%.

Questions: What types of companies did Lynch favor in 1981?
Answers: John Blair (broadcaster), Tandy (Radio Shack), Quixote (plastic barriers), Telecredit, ChemLawn, Seven Oaks (coupon processor), various restaurant chains.

Questions: Why was Lynch impressed with restaurant chains and retailers?
Answers: By expanding across the country, these companies could maintain 20% growth rates for 10-15 years with favorable math.

Questions: Why did Lynch prefer retailers and restaurants over high-tech companies?
Answers: They were less risky - a computer company can lose half its value overnight, but a donut chain won't lose business when a competitor opens in another state.

Questions: What was Lynch's biggest holding at the end of 1981?
Answers: Mattel, the toy maker, which was 3% of the fund.

Questions: What characterized Lynch's top 10 holdings in early 1982?
Answers: Companies like Chemical Bank, Pic 'N' Save, Verbatim, Horn & Hardart, and Pep Boys - strong balance sheets with favorable prospects.

Questions: Why could Lynch buy offbeat companies like Seven Oaks?
Answers: In a wide-open fund like Magellan, nobody was looking over his shoulder, unlike managers subject to hierarchical second-guessing.

Questions: What does Lynch say about professional responsibility and monitoring?
Answers: When you have to worry about what someone behind you thinks, you cease to be professional and doubt your ability to succeed.

Questions: What luxury did Lynch have by 1982?
Answers: Instead of selling one stock to buy another, new money was pouring in at $40-71 million per month, allowing him to maintain old positions while initiating new ones.

Questions: How did Lynch's stock focus change as Magellan grew?
Answers: Ironically, when Magellan was small he concentrated on bigger stocks, and when it became bigger he found himself concentrating on smaller stocks.

Questions: Why was Lynch depressed by the early 1983 market?
Answers: The Dow had advanced 300 points from 1982 lows, technology issues reached giddy heights - he preferred corrections that created bargains.

Questions: What does Lynch say about bargains and market sell-offs?
Answers: Bargains are the holy grail of the true stockpicker; corrections are opportunities to acquire more shares at low prices, not disasters.

Questions: What remained Lynch's biggest holding through 1983?
Answers: Chrysler remained at 5% of the fund (SEC maximum) and stayed his biggest holding for most of the year.

Questions: What was the structure of Lynch's day by the mid-1980s?
Answers: 6:05 AM carpool, 6:45 arrival, morning preparation, trading orders by 8 AM, then constant phone calls and company research until late.

Questions: How many companies did Lynch visit annually?
Answers: His visits escalated from 214 in 1980 to 330 in 1982, 489 in 1983, 411 in 1984, 463 in 1985, and 570 in 1986.

Questions: What was Lynch's approach to corporate lunches as Magellan grew?
Answers: He cut back on lunches in favor of more efficient phone calls while eating sandwiches, having developed enough sources from earlier lunches.

Questions: How did Lynch's office setup facilitate his work style?
Answers: Four secretaries led by Paula Sullivan routed calls, chairs had become file cabinets so visitors couldn't sit, forcing brief interactions.

Questions: What was Lynch's rule about keeping up with companies?
Answers: He kept detailed notebooks of every contact with companies, including stock prices and story summaries, essential for tracking hundreds of investments.

Questions: How did Lynch use his Saturday work time?
Answers: Devoted to cleaning his desk, reviewing three-foot-high stacks of mail, perusing annual reports in February/March, and reviewing company notebooks.

Questions: What was Lynch's Saturday goal?
Answers: To see some wood (desktop) at the end of the afternoon, though he didn't always achieve it.

Questions: How did Lynch handle the terrible first half of 1982?
Answers: Prime rate hit double digits along with inflation and unemployment; he bought Treasury bonds paying 13-14% as his biggest position.

Questions: Why did Lynch buy bonds in 1982?
Answers: Not for defensive purposes due to fear of stocks, but because bond yields exceeded normal expected returns from stocks.

Questions: What convinced Lynch not to prepare for total economic collapse?
Answers: If the economy collapsed, he'd be fishing with everyone else and portfolio strategy would be irrelevant; if not, he wanted to be in stocks and bonds.

Questions: How did Lynch approach the 1982 recession?
Answers: He assumed the worst wouldn't happen and asked 'what then?' - figuring interest rates had to come down and both stocks and bonds would profit.

Questions: How does Lynch describe the relationship between research time and number of stocks owned?
Answers: How much time you spend researching stocks is directly proportional to how many stocks you own. It takes a few hours a year to keep up with each one.

Questions: How does Lynch defend having 900 stocks in the portfolio?
Answers: An imaginative fund manager can pick 1,000+ stocks in unusual companies that will never appear in standard Wall Street portfolios, 'flying off the radar scope.'

Questions: What were Lynch's two reasons for taking tiny positions?
Answers: 1) Companies were quite small, so even owning 10% didn't amount to much, or 2) He wasn't convinced they deserved substantial commitment.

Questions: What were the results from Lynch's discount club investments?
Answers: All three made money - Costco was a triple, proving the value of following up on unexpected leads.

Questions: How many S&Ls did Lynch buy in April 1983?
Answers: 39 of his 83 new acquisitions in April 1983 were banks or S&Ls, eventually totaling 100 S&Ls making 3% of the fund.

Questions: What was Lynch's approach to building positions in auto stocks?
Answers: He made what's known as an 'industry bet' by analyzing each company case-by-case rather than arbitrarily deciding on 8% auto allocation.

Questions: Which auto companies did Lynch favor over General Motors and why?
Answers: Ford, Chrysler, and Volvo because GM was arrogant, myopic, and resting on laurels - saying it was miserable was about the nicest compliment you could give GM.

Questions: What were the profits from Lynch's major auto positions?
Answers: Well over $100 million each from Ford and Chrysler, plus $79 million from Volvo over the six-year stretch from 1982-1988.

Questions: What was the key to Magellan's superior results according to Lynch?
Answers: Huge gains in a few huge positions, not diversification across many small positions.

Questions: How does Lynch respond to concerns about 'liquidity' in stock selection?
Answers: In stocks as in romance, ease of divorce is not a sound basis for commitment - if you've chosen wisely, you won't want a divorce.

Questions: What examples does Lynch give of liquid stocks that still lost money?
Answers: Polaroid (lost 90% in 1973) and Xerox - both were actively traded and easy to sell, but fund managers still lost money by not wanting to get out.

Questions: How did Lynch acquire large positions in some stocks?
Answers: Occasionally through large institutional blocks (2 million shares of Owens-Corning, 2 million of BankAmerica), but usually through constant nibbling over months.

Questions: What determined Lynch's vacation destinations?
Answers: Time zones and phone booth locations - Austria was good because it was afternoon there before U.S. markets opened.

Questions: Where was Lynch's favorite U.S. ski location and why?
Answers: Balsam's in Dixville Notch, New Hampshire, because it had a phone at the bottom of the lift for calling in trades.

Questions: When did Lynch begin investing heavily in foreign stocks?
Answers: Foreign buying began in earnest in 1984, with Lynch being the first domestic fund manager after John Templeton to invest heavily abroad.

Questions: What was Lynch's most successful research trip?
Answers: Mid-September 1985: three weeks, 23 companies across Europe, leading to over $200 million in profits from foreign stock picks.

Questions: What happened to Lynch's luggage on the European trip?
Answers: Sabena airline lost his luggage, but he was outfitted in a proper Swedish suit by his host's husband who had his exact measurements.

Questions: What companies did Lynch visit in Sweden?
Answers: Esselte (office equipment), ASEA (conglomerate), Alfa Laval (milking machines/biogenetics), Electrolux (appliances), Aga (gases), Ericsson (telephones), Skandia (insurance).

Questions: What was special about Lynch's Volvo discovery?
Answers: The stock price was $34 and the company had $34 per share in cash, so he was getting the auto business and subsidiaries for nothing.

Questions: What lesson did Lynch learn about driving on the German autobahn?
Answers: Peter's Principle #10: Never look back when you're driving on the autobahn - he found a Mercedes three inches from his bumper at 120 mph.

Questions: Why couldn't Lynch visit Sandoz in Switzerland?
Answers: When he called to arrange a meeting, the vice-president kept asking 'Why?' to every explanation until Lynch gave up and said goodbye.

Questions: What Italian companies did Lynch visit?
Answers: Montedison (hydroelectric), IFI, and Olivetti, plus he saw The Last Supper - listing all four as his favorite northern Italian attractions.

Questions: What was Lynch's insight about Italy in 1985?
Answers: Italy was like America in the 1940s-50s - a place where appliance companies, electric companies, and supermarkets would be future fast growers.

Questions: What were Lynch's top eleven foreign stock gains?
Answers: Peugeot, Volvo, Skandia, Esselte, Electrolux, Aga, Norsk Hydro, Montedison, IFI, Tobu Railway, and Kinki Nippon Railway made over $200 million in profits.

Questions: Which was Lynch's biggest foreign stock winner?
Answers: Tobu Railway with 386% gain in five years, though it was only 0.13% of Magellan's assets.

Questions: What was Lynch's experience calling trades from Yosemite?
Answers: Standing in a phone booth overlooking mountains, he spent two hours giving trades and only got from A's through L's in his alphabetical holdings list.

Questions: What major tactical shift did Lynch make in 1987?
Answers: He began deemphasizing autos and upgrading financial companies, particularly Fannie Mae and S&Ls, as the economic recovery matured.

Questions: What kept Lynch motivated despite the 'too big' criticism?
Answers: Skeptics said $1B, $2B, $4B, $6B, $8B, and $10B were all too big, and he was determined to prove them wrong.

Questions: What was Lynch's approach to preparing shareholders for volatility?
Answers: He warned in annual reports of Magellan's tendency to get swamped in choppy waters, believing preparation prevents panic.

Questions: What forced Lynch to sell during the 1987 crash?
Answers: $689 million in sales and $1.3 billion in redemptions in October, forcing him to be a seller when he'd prefer to be a buyer.

Questions: What lesson does Lynch draw about shareholders and fund performance?
Answers: Shareholders play a major role in success or failure - if they refuse to panic, fund managers won't have to liquidate at unfavorable prices.

Questions: What is Lynch's warning about cyclicals?
Answers: Cyclicals are like blackjack - stay in the game too long and it's bound to take back all your profit.

Questions: What stocks became Lynch's focus after reducing autos?
Answers: Growth stocks with high-quality operations: Philip Morris, RJR Nabisco, Eastman Kodak, Merck, Atlantic Richfield, plus General Electric.

Questions: What was Lynch's biggest single stock winner?
Answers: Fannie Mae, where Magellan made $500 million profit in five years, while all Fidelity funds combined made over $1 billion - possibly an all-time record.

Questions: What were Lynch's second through fourth biggest winners?
Answers: Ford ($199 million from 1985-1989), Philip Morris ($111 million), and MCI ($92 million).

Questions: What characterized Lynch's nine all-time winners?
Answers: Two automakers, cigarette/food company, tobacco/insurance conglomerate, electric utility with accident, telephone company, diversified financial company, entertainment company, student loan buyer.

Questions: What does Lynch say about his most consistent losers?
Answers: Technology stocks were his most consistent losers, including $25 million on Digital in 1988, plus losses on Tandem, Motorola, Texas Instruments, and IBM.

Questions: What does Lynch say about stockpicking being reducible to a formula?
Answers: Stockpicking can't be reduced to a simple formula or recipe that guarantees success - the 160+ pages describing his 21 stock picks prove this.

Questions: How does Lynch describe stockpicking as both art and science?
Answers: Stockpicking is both art and science, but too much of either is dangerous - pure measurement or pure intuition both lead to poor results.

Questions: What historical example does Lynch give of measurement obsession?
Answers: Thales, the early Greek philosopher who was so intent on counting stars that he kept falling into potholes in the road.

Questions: How does Lynch describe the 'art' approach to investing?
Answers: The realm of intuition and passion where artistic types believe success is about having a knack and following hunches, leading to neglect of research.

Questions: What tools does Lynch prefer over high-tech trading systems?
Answers: Lynch uses a basic Quotron, not the newfangled workstations with elaborate features - he believes professionals are missing the point with fancy software.

Questions: What does Lynch say about Warren Buffett and technology?
Answers: Trust me, Warren Buffett doesn't use fancy trading software and technology systems.

Questions: Where should professional investors spend more time according to Lynch?
Answers: They should spend more time at the mall rather than scrambling to buy services to find out what other professionals are doing.

Questions: How many stocks did Lynch recommend in previous Barron's panels?
Answers: 1986: over 100 stocks, 1987: 226 stocks, 1988: 122 stocks, 1989: 91 stocks, 1990: 73 stocks.

Questions: What was Alan Abelson's reaction to Lynch's extensive recommendations?
Answers: Maybe we should have asked you what you don't like' and 'You are an equal-opportunity buyer. You're being nondiscriminatory.'

Questions: What is Lynch's philosophy about searching for companies?
Answers: Searching for companies is like looking for grubs under rocks: turn over 10 rocks, find one grub; turn over 20 rocks, find two grubs.

Questions: How many recommendations did Lynch make in 1991 and 1992?
Answers: 21 companies in 1991 and 21 again in 1992, reduced from his full-time days due to part-time status.

Questions: How did Lynch feel about the overpriced market in January 1992?
Answers: He was the most depressed person on the panel because overpriced markets with stocks hitting new highs are harder to find bargains in.

Questions: What does Lynch prefer - rising or falling markets?
Answers: The devoted stockpicker is happier when the market drops 300 points than when it rises the same amount, because drops create bargains.

Questions: What was Lynch's prediction for growth stocks in 1992?
Answers: Much-ballyhooed growth stocks that were 1991 champions would do nothing or go sideways in 1992, or suffer 30% declines in a bad market.

Questions: Where did Lynch expect to find bargains in 1992?
Answers: In small stocks, where he expected bargains while large growth stocks were overpriced.

Questions: What does Lynch say about reviewing previous stock picks?
Answers: Don't pick new companies just for another quote to watch - getting involved with manageable numbers and confining buys/sells to these is a good strategy.

Questions: What is the common practice Lynch criticizes about stock trading?
Answers: Buying, selling, and forgetting a long string of companies is not likely to succeed, yet many investors continue this approach.

Questions: How does Lynch keep track of his investment stories?
Answers: He carries large wire-bound notebooks recording important details from quarterly/annual reports plus reasons for buying/selling each stock.

Questions: What does Lynch compare his notebooks to?
Answers: Other people thumbing through love letters found in the attic - he reviews these investment stories at home or on the way to office.

Questions: How did Lynch review his 21 selections from 1991?
Answers: It was a mixed bag that did extremely well, rising 50%+ while S&P rose 30%, including various sectors from insurance to biotechnology.

Questions: What were some of Lynch's 1991 stock recommendations?
Answers: Kemper, Household International, Cedar Fair, EQK Green Acres, Reebok, Caesars World, Phelps Dodge, Coca-Cola Enterprises, Genentech, AFLAC, K mart.

Questions: Why did Lynch reject Cedar Fair for 1992?
Answers: The stock had risen from under $12 to $18, reducing yield from 11% to 8.5%, with no indication of improved earnings ahead.

Questions: What warning sign did Lynch see in EQK Green Acres' quarterly report?
Answers: The company was debating whether to pay the regular quarterly dividend increase of one cent to save $100,000 - breaking a 6-year string for paltry savings.

Questions: What does Lynch say about buying on bad news vs. good news?
Answers: Buy at sound of cannons, sell at sound of trumpets' can be misguided - buying on bad news can be costly since bad news often gets worse.

Questions: What is Lynch's preference regarding news and stock purchases?
Answers: Buying on good news is healthier long-run; wait for proof rather than rumors to improve odds considerably.

Questions: What does Lynch say about year-end bargain hunting?
Answers: Act quickly! Bargain hunters find bargains fast these days, and by the time they're finished buying, stocks aren't bargains anymore.

Questions: What happened to Toll Brothers stock that Lynch identified as a bargain?
Answers: He found it at $2.38 (down from $12.63), put it at top of his list in October, but it quadrupled to $8 before he could publish the recommendation.

Questions: Why does Lynch look for companies that benefit subtly from overblown crises?
Answers: When markets overreact to news, there are often indirect beneficiaries that get overlooked but will profit when conditions normalize.

Questions: What approach does Lynch take to continuing sagas vs. disconnected events?
Answers: He thinks of investments as continuing sagas needing periodic review for new plot twists rather than disconnected events.

Questions: What does Lynch say about the January 1992 market atmosphere?
Answers: In the festive atmosphere of a recent 300-point Dow gain, optimism abounded, but Lynch was most depressed by the overpriced conditions.

Questions: Where does Lynch find his favorite source of investment ideas?
Answers: The Burlington Mall, located 25 miles from his hometown of Marblehead.

Questions: What investment strategy does Lynch say is superior to taking a stockbroker's advice?
Answers: Hanging out at the mall is far superior to taking a stockbroker's advice on faith or combing financial press for tips.

Questions: What example does Lynch give of retail investment success?
Answers: $10,000 invested in 1986 in each of Home Depot, Limited, Gap, and Wal-Mart, held for 5 years, was worth over $500,000 by end of 1991.

Questions: What retail companies does Lynch pass on his drive to Burlington Mall?
Answers: Two Radio Shacks (Tandy), Toys 'R' Us, Kids 'R' Us, Ames Department Store, LensCrafters, Howard Johnson's, Taco Bell, and Chili's.

Questions: What does Lynch note about Toys 'R' Us performance?
Answers: It went from 25 cents to $36, representing a massive return for early investors.

Questions: What does Lynch say about the mall's resemblance to an old town square?
Answers: It reminds him of an old town square with ponds, park benches, trees, and promenade, but with 160 enterprises instead of traditional shops.

Questions: What makes retail investing particularly profitable according to Lynch?
Answers: The homogeneity of taste in food and fashion that makes for dull culture also makes fortunes for retail and restaurant company owners.

Questions: What examples does Lynch give of successful retail expansion?
Answers: Westward Ho of Home Depot (Atlanta), Eastward Ho of Taco Bell (California), Southward Ho of Lands' End (Wisconsin), Northward Ho of Wal-Mart (Arkansas).

Questions: How did Lynch's daughters lead him to investment ideas?
Answers: Annie asked 'Is Clearly Canadian a public company?' and they often wore Chili's sweatshirts, but Lynch ignored these signals initially.

Questions: What was Lynch's mistake with Clearly Canadian?
Answers: He looked it up, didn't see it in S&P book, and forgot about it. The stock went from $3 to $26.75 (9-bagger) in one year after going public in 1991.

Questions: What does Lynch say about children as investment advisors?
Answers: Children are part of an international tribe with same taste in caps, T-shirts, socks, and jeans - when his daughter shops at Gap, teenagers nationwide are doing the same.

Questions: When did Lynch's daughter Mary initiate coverage on the Gap?
Answers: Summer 1990, buying school wardrobe from the Burlington Mall store when Gap had moved beyond just jeans to colorful new merchandise.

Questions: What led Lynch to investigate the Body Shop?
Answers: His three daughters headed there during a 'Christmas present trip' that was actually Lynch's research expedition.

Questions: Who first recommended Body Shop to Lynch and when?
Answers: Analyst Monica Kalmanson recommended it at a 1990 Fidelity meeting, and head librarian Cathy Stephenson left to open a Body Shop franchise.

Questions: What was Lynch's embarrassing discovery about Body Shop?
Answers: He had already bought shares in 1989 and forgotten - it was one of many 'tune in later' stocks in his 1,400-company portfolio.

Questions: What impressed Lynch about the Body Shop's expansion approach?
Answers: The company was proceeding carefully and expanding with caution, requiring chairman approval even for proven franchisees' second stores.

Questions: What is Lynch's rule of thumb for growth stock pricing?
Answers: A stock should sell at or below its growth rate - even fastest-growing companies rarely achieve more than 25% growth sustainably.

Questions: How did Lynch compare Body Shop to Coca-Cola valuations?
Answers: Body Shop: 30% grower at 40x earnings vs. Coca-Cola: 15% grower at 30x earnings - he preferred the higher growth despite higher multiple.

Questions: What gave Lynch confidence in Body Shop's global potential?
Answers: It was international almost from the start, installed on six continents, had hardly scratched the surface of any of them.

Questions: What does Lynch say about Wal-Mart's long-term success story?
Answers: Shows how stocks that have gone up 10-50 fold can still go higher - Wal-Mart was a great investment in multiple decades.

Questions: What is Lynch's key insight about retail company growth?
Answers: As long as same-store sales increase, company isn't crippled by excessive debt, and follows expansion plans, it usually pays to stick with the stock.

Questions: What does Lynch say about getting in 'too late' on successful stocks?
Answers: If anybody tells you a stock that's gone up 10-50 fold can't go higher, show them the Wal-Mart chart.

Questions: What does Lynch say about investing in fearsome places?
Answers: You've got to go into places where other investors and fund managers fear to tread - the most fearsome places in 1991 were connected to housing and real estate.

Questions: What evidence did Lynch see of real estate despair in his neighborhood?
Answers: So many for-sale signs sprouted in Marblehead that the for-sale sign seemed like the new state flower of Massachusetts.

Questions: What other quiet facts supported Lynch's contrarian view?
Answers: The 'affordability index' from National Association of Home Builders and percentage of mortgage loans in default told a different story than headlines.

Questions: What is Lynch's technique for investing in troubled industries?
Answers: Wait until prevailing opinion is that things have gone from bad to worse, then buy shares in the strongest companies in the group.

Questions: When is Lynch's technique for troubled industries NOT reliable?
Answers: When quiet facts don't support improvement - oil and gas drilling industries kept getting worse since 1984 despite people saying they couldn't get worse.

Questions: Why did Lynch choose Toll Brothers for further study?
Answers: He remembered it as a strong company with financial wherewithal to survive hard times, recommended by Ken Heebner and Alan Leifer.

Questions: What positive factors did Lynch find in Toll Brothers' situation?
Answers: Debt had fallen $28 million, cash was up $22 million, balance sheet improved, and they had a two-year backlog of orders.

Questions: How did Lynch approach the Pier 1 investment opportunity?
Answers: He realized people moving into houses would need lamps, room dividers, place mats, rugs, and furniture that Pier 1 sold at affordable prices.

Questions: What is the key retail indicator Lynch always checks?
Answers: Same-store sales - when they decline in prosperity it's worrying, but decline during recession is normal and even modest positive is good.

Questions: How did Lynch analyze Pier 1's inventory situation?
Answers: Inventories had increased but only because of 25 new stores needing stock; otherwise at acceptable levels, unlike companies covering up poor sales.

Questions: What was Pier 1's valuation when Lynch recommended it?
Answers: $7 stock with P/E ratio of 10 based on 70-cent earnings estimate, while growing at 15% annual rate.

Questions: Who does Lynch imagine might want to acquire Pier 1?
Answers: K mart, which was pleased with earlier acquisitions of drug, book, and office supply chains and always looking for expansion opportunities.

Questions: How did Pier 1 lead Lynch to Sunbelt Nursery?
Answers: One stock leads to another - Lynch realized lawn and garden business would benefit from housing rebound just like lampshade and dish rack business.

Questions: What opportunity did Lynch see in the nursery business?
Answers: It was one of the last mom-and-pop enterprises not supplanted by chains - opportunity for well-managed chain to do for flower beds what Dunkin' Donuts did for donuts.
